segment.source: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V
segment.target: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V

segment.source: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V
segment.target: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V

segment.source: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V
segment.target: Deploying Microsoft Office 2013 by Using App-V

segment.source: Use the information in this article to use Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0, or later versions, to deliver Microsoft Office 2013 as a virtualized application to computers in your organization.
segment.target: Use the information in this article to use Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0, or later versions, to deliver Microsoft Office 2013 as a virtualized application to computers in your organization.

segment.source: For information about using App-V to deliver Office 2010, see Deploying Microsoft Office 2010 by Using App-V.
segment.target: For information about using App-V to deliver Office 2010, see Deploying Microsoft Office 2010 by Using App-V.

segment.source: To successfully deploy Office 2013 with App-V, you need to be familiar with Office 2013 and pp-V.
segment.target: To successfully deploy Office 2013 with App-V, you need to be familiar with Office 2013 and pp-V.

segment.source: This topic contains the following sections:
segment.target: This topic contains the following sections:

segment.source: What to know before you start
segment.target: What to know before you start

segment.source: Creating an Office 2013 package for App-V with the Office Deployment Tool
segment.target: Creating an Office 2013 package for App-V with the Office Deployment Tool

segment.source: Publishing the Office package for App-V 5.0
segment.target: Publishing the Office package for App-V 5.0

segment.source: Customizing and managing Office App-V packages
segment.target: Customizing and managing Office App-V packages

segment.source: What to know before you start
segment.target: What to know before you start

segment.source: Before you deploy Office 2013 by using App-V, review the following planning information.
segment.target: Before you deploy Office 2013 by using App-V, review the following planning information.

segment.target: Use the following table to get information about supported versions of Office and about running coexisting versions of Office.

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.target: Planning for Using App-V with Office

segment.source: Supported versions of Office
segment.target: Supported versions of Office

segment.source: Supported deployment types (for example, desktop, personal Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI), pooled VDI)
segment.target: Supported deployment types (for example, desktop, personal Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI), pooled VDI)

segment.source: Office licensing options
segment.target: Office licensing options

segment.source: Planning for Using App-V with Office
segment.target: Planning for Using App-V with Office

segment.source: Considerations for installing different versions of Office on the same computer
segment.target: Considerations for installing different versions of Office on the same computer

segment.source: Packaging, publishing, and deployment requirements
segment.target: Packaging, publishing, and deployment requirements

segment.source: Before you deploy Office by using App-V, review the following requirements.
segment.target: Before you deploy Office by using App-V, review the following requirements.

segment.source: Task
segment.target: Task

segment.source: Requirement
segment.target: Requirement

segment.source: Packaging
segment.target: Packaging

segment.source: All of the Office applications that you want to deploy to users must be in a single package.
segment.target: All of the Office applications that you want to deploy to users must be in a single package.

segment.source: In App-V 5.0 and later, you must use the Office Deployment Tool to create packages.
segment.target: In App-V 5.0 and later, you must use the Office Deployment Tool to create packages.

segment.source: You cannot use the Sequencer.
segment.target: You cannot use the Sequencer.

segment.source: If you are deploying Microsoft Visio 2013 and Microsoft Project 2013 along with Office, you must include them in the same package with Office.
segment.target: If you are deploying Microsoft Visio 2013 and Microsoft Project 2013 along with Office, you must include them in the same package with Office.

segment.source: For more information, see Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office.
segment.target: For more information, see Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office.

segment.source: Publishing
segment.target: Publishing

segment.source: You can publish only one Office package to each client computer.
segment.target: You can publish only one Office package to each client computer.

segment.source: You must publish the Office package globally.
segment.target: You must publish the Office package globally.

segment.source: You cannot publish to the user.
segment.target: You cannot publish to the user.

segment.source: Deploying any of the following products to a shared computer, for example, by using Remote Desktop Services:
segment.target: Deploying any of the following products to a shared computer, for example, by using Remote Desktop Services:

segment.source: Office 365 ProPlus
segment.target: Office 365 ProPlus

segment.source: Visio Pro for Office 365
segment.target: Visio Pro for Office 365

segment.source: Project Pro for Office 365
segment.target: Project Pro for Office 365

segment.source: You must enable shared computer activation.
segment.target: You must enable shared computer activation.

segment.source: You don’t use shared computer activation if you’re deploying a volume licensed product, such as:
segment.target: You don’t use shared computer activation if you’re deploying a volume licensed product, such as:

segment.source: Office Professional Plus 2013
segment.target: Office Professional Plus 2013

segment.source: Visio Professional 2013
segment.target: Visio Professional 2013

segment.source: Project Professional 2013
segment.target: Project Professional 2013

segment.source: Excluding Office applications from a package
segment.target: Excluding Office applications from a package

segment.source: The following table describes the recommended methods for excluding specific Office applications from a package.
segment.target: The following table describes the recommended methods for excluding specific Office applications from a package.

segment.source: Task
segment.target: Task

segment.source: Details
segment.target: Details

segment.source: Use the ExcludeApp setting when you create the package by using the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: Use the ExcludeApp setting when you create the package by using the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: Enables you to exclude specific Office applications from the package when the Office Deployment Tool creates the package.
segment.target: Enables you to exclude specific Office applications from the package when the Office Deployment Tool creates the package.

segment.source: For example, you can use this setting to create a package that contains only Microsoft Word.
segment.target: For example, you can use this setting to create a package that contains only Microsoft Word.

segment.source: For more information, see ExcludeApp element.
segment.target: For more information, see ExcludeApp element.

segment.source: Modify the DeploymentConfig.xml file
segment.target: Modify the DeploymentConfig.xml file

segment.source: Modify the DeploymentConfig.xml file after the package has been created.
segment.target: Modify the DeploymentConfig.xml file after the package has been created.

segment.source: This file contains the default package settings for all users on a computer that is running the App-V Client.
segment.target: This file contains the default package settings for all users on a computer that is running the App-V Client.

segment.source: For more information, see Disabling Office 2013 applications.
segment.target: For more information, see Disabling Office 2013 applications.

segment.source: Creating an Office 2013 package for App-V with the Office Deployment Tool
segment.target: Creating an Office 2013 package for App-V with the Office Deployment Tool

segment.source: Complete the following steps to create an Office 2013 package for App-V 5.0 or later.
segment.target: Complete the following steps to create an Office 2013 package for App-V 5.0 or later.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: In App-V 5.0 and later, you must the Office Deployment Tool to create a package.
segment.target: In App-V 5.0 and later, you must the Office Deployment Tool to create a package.

segment.source: You cannot use the Sequencer to create packages.
segment.target: You cannot use the Sequencer to create packages.

segment.source: Review prerequisites for using the Office Deployment Tool
segment.target: Review prerequisites for using the Office Deployment Tool

segment.source: The computer on which you are installing the Office Deployment Tool must have:
segment.target: The computer on which you are installing the Office Deployment Tool must have:

segment.source: Prerequisite
segment.target: Prerequisite

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Prerequisite software
segment.target: Prerequisite software

segment.source: .Net Framework 4
segment.target: .Net Framework 4

segment.source: Supported operating systems
segment.target: Supported operating systems

segment.source: 64-bit version of Windows 8
segment.target: 64-bit version of Windows 8

segment.source: 64-bit version of Windows 7
segment.target: 64-bit version of Windows 7

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In this topic, the term “Office 2013 App-V package” refers to subscription licensing and volume licensing.
segment.target: In this topic, the term “Office 2013 App-V package” refers to subscription licensing and volume licensing.

segment.source: Create Office 2013 App-V Packages Using Office Deployment Tool
segment.target: Create Office 2013 App-V Packages Using Office Deployment Tool

segment.source: You create Office 2013 App-V packages by using the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: You create Office 2013 App-V packages by using the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: The following instructions explain how to create an Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing or Subscription Licensing.
segment.target: The following instructions explain how to create an Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing or Subscription Licensing.

segment.source: Create Office 2013 App-V packages on 64-bit Windows computers.
segment.target: Create Office 2013 App-V packages on 64-bit Windows computers.

segment.source: Once created, the Office 2013 App-V package will run on 32-bit and 64-bit Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.
segment.target: Once created, the Office 2013 App-V package will run on 32-bit and 64-bit Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.

segment.source: Download the Office Deployment Tool
segment.target: Download the Office Deployment Tool

segment.source: Office 2013 App-V Packages are created using the Office Deployment Tool, which generates an Office 2013 App-V Package.
segment.target: Office 2013 App-V Packages are created using the Office Deployment Tool, which generates an Office 2013 App-V Package.

segment.source: The package cannot be created or modified through the App-V sequencer.
segment.target: The package cannot be created or modified through the App-V sequencer.

segment.source: To begin package creation:
segment.target: To begin package creation:

segment.source: Download the Office Deployment Tool for Click-to-Run.
segment.target: Download the Office Deployment Tool for Click-to-Run.

segment.source: Run the .exe file and extract its features into the desired location.
segment.target: Run the .exe file and extract its features into the desired location.

segment.source: To make this process easier, you can create a shared network folder where the features will be saved.
segment.target: To make this process easier, you can create a shared network folder where the features will be saved.

segment.source: Example: ServerOffice2013
segment.target: Example: ServerOffice2013

segment.source: Check that a setup.exe and a configuration.xml file exist and are in the location you specified.
segment.target: Check that a setup.exe and a configuration.xml file exist and are in the location you specified.

segment.source: Download Office 2013 applications
segment.target: Download Office 2013 applications

segment.source: After you download the Office Deployment Tool, you can use it to get the latest Office 2013 applications.
segment.target: After you download the Office Deployment Tool, you can use it to get the latest Office 2013 applications.

segment.source: After getting the Office applications, you create the Office 2013 App-V package.
segment.target: After getting the Office applications, you create the Office 2013 App-V package.

segment.source: The XML file that is included in the Office Deployment Tool specifies the product details, such as the languages and Office applications included.
segment.target: The XML file that is included in the Office Deployment Tool specifies the product details, such as the languages and Office applications included.

segment.source: Customize the sample XML configuration file: Use the sample XML configuration file that you downloaded with the Office Deployment Tool to customize the Office applications:
segment.target: Customize the sample XML configuration file: Use the sample XML configuration file that you downloaded with the Office Deployment Tool to customize the Office applications:

segment.source: Open the sample XML file in Notepad or your favorite text editor.
segment.target: Open the sample XML file in Notepad or your favorite text editor.

segment.source: With the sample configuration.xml file open and ready for editing, you can specify products, languages, and the path to which you save the Office 2013 applications.
segment.target: With the sample configuration.xml file open and ready for editing, you can specify products, languages, and the path to which you save the Office 2013 applications.

segment.source: The following is a basic example of the configuration.xml file:
segment.target: The following is a basic example of the configuration.xml file:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The configuration XML is a sample XML file.
segment.target: The configuration XML is a sample XML file.

segment.source: The file includes lines that are commented out.
segment.target: The file includes lines that are commented out.

segment.source: You can “uncomment” these lines to customize additional settings with the file.
segment.target: You can “uncomment” these lines to customize additional settings with the file.

segment.source: The above XML configuration file specifies that Office 2013 ProPlus 32-bit edition, including Visio ProPlus, will be downloaded in English to the serverOffice 2013, which is the location where Office applications will be saved to.
segment.target: The above XML configuration file specifies that Office 2013 ProPlus 32-bit edition, including Visio ProPlus, will be downloaded in English to the serverOffice 2013, which is the location where Office applications will be saved to.

segment.source: Note that the Product ID of the applications will not affect the final licensing of Office.
segment.target: Note that the Product ID of the applications will not affect the final licensing of Office.

segment.source: Office 2013 App-V packages with various licensing can be created from the same applications through specifying licensing in a later stage.
segment.target: Office 2013 App-V packages with various licensing can be created from the same applications through specifying licensing in a later stage.

segment.source: The table below summarizes the customizable attributes and elements of XML file:
segment.target: The table below summarizes the customizable attributes and elements of XML file:

segment.source: Input
segment.target: Input

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Example
segment.target: Example

segment.source: Add element
segment.target: Add element

segment.source: Specifies the products and languages to include in the package.
segment.target: Specifies the products and languages to include in the package.

segment.source: N/A
segment.target: N/A

segment.source: OfficeClientEdition (attribute of Add element)
segment.target: OfficeClientEdition (attribute of Add element)

segment.source: Specifies the edition of Office 2013 product to use: 32-bit or 64-bit.
segment.target: Specifies the edition of Office 2013 product to use: 32-bit or 64-bit.

segment.source: The operation fails if OfficeClientEdition is not set to a valid value.
segment.target: The operation fails if OfficeClientEdition is not set to a valid value.

segment.source: OfficeClientEdition32
segment.target: OfficeClientEdition32

segment.source: OfficeClientEdition64
segment.target: OfficeClientEdition64

segment.source: Product element
segment.target: Product element

segment.source: Specifies the application.
segment.target: Specifies the application.

segment.source: Project 2013 and Visio 2013 must be specified here as an added product to be included in the applications.
segment.target: Project 2013 and Visio 2013 must be specified here as an added product to be included in the applications.

segment.source: Language element
segment.target: Language element

segment.source: Specifies the language supported in the applications
segment.target: Specifies the language supported in the applications

segment.source: Version (attribute of Add element)
segment.target: Version (attribute of Add element)

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies a build to use for the package
segment.target: Specifies a build to use for the package

segment.source: Defaults to latest advertised build (as defined in v32.CAB at the Office source).
segment.target: Defaults to latest advertised build (as defined in v32.CAB at the Office source).

segment.source: SourcePath (attribute of Add element)
segment.target: SourcePath (attribute of Add element)

segment.source: Specifies the location in which the applications will be saved to.
segment.target: Specifies the location in which the applications will be saved to.

segment.source: After editing the configuration.xml file to specify the desired product, languages, and also the location which the Office 2013 applications will be saved onto, you can save the configuration file, for example, as Customconfig.xml.
segment.target: After editing the configuration.xml file to specify the desired product, languages, and also the location which the Office 2013 applications will be saved onto, you can save the configuration file, for example, as Customconfig.xml.

segment.source: Download the applications into the specified location: Use an elevated command prompt and a 64 bit operating system to download the Office 2013 applications that will later be converted into an App-V package.
segment.target: Download the applications into the specified location: Use an elevated command prompt and a 64 bit operating system to download the Office 2013 applications that will later be converted into an App-V package.

segment.source: Below is an example command with description of details:
segment.target: Below is an example command with description of details:

segment.source: In the example:
segment.target: In the example:

segment.source: server\Office2013
segment.target: server\Office2013

segment.source: is the network share location that contains the Office Deployment Tool and the custom Configuration.xml file, Customconfig.xml.
segment.target: is the network share location that contains the Office Deployment Tool and the custom Configuration.xml file, Customconfig.xml.

segment.source: Setup.exe
segment.target: Setup.exe

segment.source: is the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: is the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: /download
segment.target: /download

segment.source: downloads the Office 2013 applications that you specify in the customConfig.xml file.
segment.target: downloads the Office 2013 applications that you specify in the customConfig.xml file.

segment.source: These bits can be later converted in an Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing.
segment.target: These bits can be later converted in an Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing.

segment.source: server\Office2013\Customconfig.xml
segment.target: server\Office2013\Customconfig.xml

segment.source: passes the XML configuration file required to complete the download process, in this example, customconfig.xml.
segment.target: passes the XML configuration file required to complete the download process, in this example, customconfig.xml.

segment.source: After using the download command, Office applications should be found in the location specified in the configuration xml file, in this example Server\Office2013.
segment.target: After using the download command, Office applications should be found in the location specified in the configuration xml file, in this example Server\Office2013.

segment.source: Convert the Office applications into an App-V package
segment.target: Convert the Office applications into an App-V package

segment.source: After you download the Office 2013 applications through the Office Deployment Tool, use the Office Deployment Tool to convert them into an Office 2013 App-V package.
segment.target: After you download the Office 2013 applications through the Office Deployment Tool, use the Office Deployment Tool to convert them into an Office 2013 App-V package.

segment.source: Complete the steps that correspond to your licensing model.
segment.target: Complete the steps that correspond to your licensing model.

segment.source: Summary of what you’ll need to do:
segment.target: Summary of what you’ll need to do:

segment.source: Create the Office 2013 App-V packages on 64-bit Windows computers.
segment.target: Create the Office 2013 App-V packages on 64-bit Windows computers.

segment.source: However, the package will run on 32-bit and 64-bit Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.
segment.target: However, the package will run on 32-bit and 64-bit Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.

segment.source: Create an Office App-V package for either Subscription Licensing package or Volume Licensing by using the Office Deployment Tool, and then modify the CustomConfig.xml configuration file.
segment.target: Create an Office App-V package for either Subscription Licensing package or Volume Licensing by using the Office Deployment Tool, and then modify the CustomConfig.xml configuration file.

segment.source: The following table summarizes the values you need to enter in the CustomConfig.xml file for the licensing model you’re using.
segment.target: The following table summarizes the values you need to enter in the CustomConfig.xml file for the licensing model you’re using.

segment.source: The steps in the sections that follow the table will specify the exact entries you need to make.
segment.target: The steps in the sections that follow the table will specify the exact entries you need to make.

segment.target: Product ID

segment.source: How to convert the Office applications into an App-V package
segment.target: How to convert the Office applications into an App-V package

segment.source: In Notepad, reopen the CustomConfig.xml file, and make the following changes to the file:
segment.target: In Notepad, reopen the CustomConfig.xml file, and make the following changes to the file:

segment.source: Parameter
segment.target: Parameter

segment.source: What to change the value to
segment.target: What to change the value to

segment.source: SourcePath
segment.target: SourcePath

segment.source: Point to the Office applications downloaded earlier.
segment.target: Point to the Office applications downloaded earlier.

segment.source: ProductID
segment.target: ProductID

segment.source: Specify the type of licensing, as shown in the following examples:
segment.target: Specify the type of licensing, as shown in the following examples:

segment.source: Subscription Licensing
segment.target: Subscription Licensing

segment.source: In this example, the following changes were made to create a package with Subscription licensing:
segment.target: In this example, the following changes were made to create a package with Subscription licensing:

segment.source: SourcePath
segment.target: SourcePath

segment.source: is the path, which was changed to point to the Office applications that were downloaded earlier.
segment.target: is the path, which was changed to point to the Office applications that were downloaded earlier.

segment.target: Product ID

segment.source: for Office was changed to .
segment.target: for Office was changed to .

segment.target: Product ID

segment.source: for Visio was changed to .
segment.target: for Visio was changed to .

segment.source: Volume Licensing
segment.target: Volume Licensing

segment.source: In this example, the following changes were made to create a package with Volume licensing:
segment.target: In this example, the following changes were made to create a package with Volume licensing:

segment.source: SourcePath
segment.target: SourcePath

segment.source: is the path, which was changed to point to the Office applications that were downloaded earlier.
segment.target: is the path, which was changed to point to the Office applications that were downloaded earlier.

segment.source: Product ID
segment.target: Product ID

segment.source: for Office was changed to .
segment.target: for Office was changed to .

segment.source: Product ID
segment.target: Product ID

segment.source: for Visio was changed to .
segment.target: for Visio was changed to .

segment.source: ExcludeApp (optional)
segment.target: ExcludeApp (optional)

segment.source: Lets you specify Office programs that you don’t want included in the App-V package that the Office Deployment Tool creates.
segment.target: Lets you specify Office programs that you don’t want included in the App-V package that the Office Deployment Tool creates.

segment.source: For example, you can exclude Access and InfoPath.
segment.target: For example, you can exclude Access and InfoPath.

segment.source: PACKAGEGUID (optional)
segment.target: PACKAGEGUID (optional)

segment.source: By default, all App-V packages created by the Office Deployment Tool share the same App-V Package ID.
segment.target: By default, all App-V packages created by the Office Deployment Tool share the same App-V Package ID.

segment.source: You can use PACKAGEGUID to specify a different package ID for each package, which allows you to publish multiple App-V packages, created by the Office Deployment Tool, and manage them by using the App-V Server.
segment.target: You can use PACKAGEGUID to specify a different package ID for each package, which allows you to publish multiple App-V packages, created by the Office Deployment Tool, and manage them by using the App-V Server.

segment.source: An example of when to use this parameter is if you create different packages for different users.
segment.target: An example of when to use this parameter is if you create different packages for different users.

segment.source: For example, you can create a package with just Office 2013 for some users, and create another package with Office 2013 and Visio 2013 for another set of users.
segment.target: For example, you can create a package with just Office 2013 for some users, and create another package with Office 2013 and Visio 2013 for another set of users.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Even if you use unique package IDs, you can still deploy only one App-V package to a single device.
segment.target: Even if you use unique package IDs, you can still deploy only one App-V package to a single device.

segment.source: Use the /packager command to convert the Office applications to an Office 2013 App-V package.
segment.target: Use the /packager command to convert the Office applications to an Office 2013 App-V package.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: In the example:
segment.target: In the example:

segment.target: server\Office2013

segment.source: is the network share location that contains the Office Deployment Tool and the custom Configuration.xml file, Customconfig.xml.
segment.target: is the network share location that contains the Office Deployment Tool and the custom Configuration.xml file, Customconfig.xml.

segment.source: Setup.exe
segment.target: Setup.exe

segment.source: is the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: is the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: /packager
segment.target: /packager

segment.source: creates the Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing as specified in the customConfig.xml file.
segment.target: creates the Office 2013 App-V package with Volume Licensing as specified in the customConfig.xml file.

segment.source: server\Office2013\Customconfig.xml
segment.target: server\Office2013\Customconfig.xml

segment.source: passes the configuration XML file (in this case customConfig) that has been prepared for the packaging stage.
segment.target: passes the configuration XML file (in this case customConfig) that has been prepared for the packaging stage.

segment.source: server\share\Office 2013AppV
segment.target: server\share\Office 2013AppV

segment.source: specifies the location of the newly created Office App-V package.
segment.target: specifies the location of the newly created Office App-V package.

segment.source: After you run the /packager command, the following folders appear up in the directory where you specified the package should be saved:
segment.target: After you run the /packager command, the following folders appear up in the directory where you specified the package should be saved:

segment.target: App-V Packages – contains an Office 2013 App-V package and two deployment configuration files.

segment.target: WorkingDir

segment.target: Note

segment.source: To troubleshoot any issues, see the log files in the %temp% directory (default).
segment.target: To troubleshoot any issues, see the log files in the %temp% directory (default).

segment.source: Verify that the Office 2013 App-V package works correctly:
segment.target: Verify that the Office 2013 App-V package works correctly:

segment.source: Publish the Office 2013 App-V package, which you created globally, to a test computer, and verify that the Office 2013 shortcuts appear.
segment.target: Publish the Office 2013 App-V package, which you created globally, to a test computer, and verify that the Office 2013 shortcuts appear.

segment.source: Start a few Office 2013 applications, such as Excel or Word, to ensure that your package is working as expected.
segment.target: Start a few Office 2013 applications, such as Excel or Word, to ensure that your package is working as expected.

segment.target: Publishing the Office package for App-V 5.0

segment.target: Use the following information to publish an Office package.

segment.target: Deploy the App-V package for Office 2013 by using the same methods you use for any other package:

segment.target: System Center Configuration Manager

segment.source: Publishing prerequisites and requirements
segment.target: Publishing prerequisites and requirements

segment.source: Prerequisite or requirement
segment.target: Prerequisite or requirement

segment.source: Details
segment.target: Details

segment.source: Enable PowerShell scripting on the App-V clients
segment.target: Enable PowerShell scripting on the App-V clients

segment.source: To publish Office 2013 packages, you must run a script.
segment.target: To publish Office 2013 packages, you must run a script.

segment.source: Package scripts are disabled by default on App-V clients.
segment.target: Package scripts are disabled by default on App-V clients.

segment.source: To enable scripting, run the following PowerShell command:
segment.target: To enable scripting, run the following PowerShell command:

segment.source: Publish the Office 2013 package globally
segment.target: Publish the Office 2013 package globally

segment.source: Extension points in the Office App-V package require installation at the computer level.
segment.target: Extension points in the Office App-V package require installation at the computer level.

segment.source: When you publish at the computer level, no prerequisite actions or redistributables are needed, and the Office 2013 package globally enables its applications to work like natively installed Office, eliminating the need for administrators to customize packages.
segment.target: When you publish at the computer level, no prerequisite actions or redistributables are needed, and the Office 2013 package globally enables its applications to work like natively installed Office, eliminating the need for administrators to customize packages.

segment.source: How to publish an Office package
segment.target: How to publish an Office package

segment.source: Run the following command to publish an Office package globally:
segment.target: Run the following command to publish an Office package globally:

segment.source: From the Web Management Console on the App-V Server, you can add permissions to a group of computers instead of to a user group to enable packages to be published globally to the computers in the corresponding group.
segment.target: From the Web Management Console on the App-V Server, you can add permissions to a group of computers instead of to a user group to enable packages to be published globally to the computers in the corresponding group.

segment.source: Customizing and managing Office App-V packages
segment.target: Customizing and managing Office App-V packages

segment.source: To manage your Office App-V packages, use the same operations as you would for any other package, but there are a few exceptions, as outlined in the following sections.
segment.target: To manage your Office App-V packages, use the same operations as you would for any other package, but there are a few exceptions, as outlined in the following sections.

segment.source: Enabling Office plug-ins by using connection groups
segment.target: Enabling Office plug-ins by using connection groups

segment.source: Disabling Office 2013 applications
segment.target: Disabling Office 2013 applications

segment.source: Disabling Office 2013 shortcuts
segment.target: Disabling Office 2013 shortcuts

segment.source: Managing Office 2013 package upgrades
segment.target: Managing Office 2013 package upgrades

segment.source: Managing Office 2013 licensing upgrades
segment.target: Managing Office 2013 licensing upgrades

segment.source: Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office
segment.target: Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office

segment.source: Enabling Office plug-ins by using connection groups
segment.target: Enabling Office plug-ins by using connection groups

segment.source: Use the steps in this section to enable Office plug-ins with your Office package.
segment.target: Use the steps in this section to enable Office plug-ins with your Office package.

segment.source: To use Office plug-ins, you must use the App-V Sequencer to create a separate package that contains just the plug-ins.
segment.target: To use Office plug-ins, you must use the App-V Sequencer to create a separate package that contains just the plug-ins.

segment.source: You cannot use the Office Deployment Tool to create the plug-ins package.
segment.target: You cannot use the Office Deployment Tool to create the plug-ins package.

segment.source: You then create a connection group that contains the Office package and the plug-ins package, as described in the following steps.
segment.target: You then create a connection group that contains the Office package and the plug-ins package, as described in the following steps.

segment.source: To enable plug-ins for Office App-V packages
segment.target: To enable plug-ins for Office App-V packages

segment.source: Add a Connection Group through App-V Server, System Center Configuration Manager, or a PowerShell cmdlet.
segment.target: Add a Connection Group through App-V Server, System Center Configuration Manager, or a PowerShell cmdlet.

segment.source: Sequence your plug-ins using the App-V 5.0 Sequencer.
segment.target: Sequence your plug-ins using the App-V 5.0 Sequencer.

segment.source: Ensure that Office 2013 is installed on the computer being used to sequence the plug-in.
segment.target: Ensure that Office 2013 is installed on the computer being used to sequence the plug-in.

segment.source: It is recommended you use Office 365 ProPlus(non-virtual) on the sequencing computer when you sequence Office 2013 plug-ins.
segment.target: It is recommended you use Office 365 ProPlus(non-virtual) on the sequencing computer when you sequence Office 2013 plug-ins.

segment.source: Create an App-V 5.0 package that includes the desired plug-ins.
segment.target: Create an App-V 5.0 package that includes the desired plug-ins.

segment.source: Add a Connection Group through App-V server, System Center Configuration Manager, or a PowerShell cmdlet.
segment.target: Add a Connection Group through App-V server, System Center Configuration Manager, or a PowerShell cmdlet.

segment.source: Add the Office 2013 App-V package and the plug-ins package you sequenced to the Connection Group you created.
segment.target: Add the Office 2013 App-V package and the plug-ins package you sequenced to the Connection Group you created.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The order of the packages in the Connection Group determines the order in which the package contents are merged.
segment.target: The order of the packages in the Connection Group determines the order in which the package contents are merged.

segment.source: In your Connection group descriptor file, add the Office 2013 App-V package first, and then add the plug-in App-V package.
segment.target: In your Connection group descriptor file, add the Office 2013 App-V package first, and then add the plug-in App-V package.

segment.source: Ensure that both packages are published to the target computer and that the plug-in package is published globally to match the global settings of the published Office 2013 App-V package.
segment.target: Ensure that both packages are published to the target computer and that the plug-in package is published globally to match the global settings of the published Office 2013 App-V package.

segment.source: Verify that the Deployment Configuration File of the plug-in package has the same settings that the Office 2013 App-V package has.
segment.target: Verify that the Deployment Configuration File of the plug-in package has the same settings that the Office 2013 App-V package has.

segment.source: Since the Office 2013 App-V package is integrated with the operating system, the plug-in package settings should match.
segment.target: Since the Office 2013 App-V package is integrated with the operating system, the plug-in package settings should match.

segment.source: You can search the Deployment Configuration File for “COM Mode” and ensure that your plug-ins package has that value set as “Integrated” and that both "InProcessEnabled" and "OutOfProcessEnabled" match the settings of the Office 2013 App-V package you published.
segment.target: You can search the Deployment Configuration File for “COM Mode” and ensure that your plug-ins package has that value set as “Integrated” and that both "InProcessEnabled" and "OutOfProcessEnabled" match the settings of the Office 2013 App-V package you published.

segment.source: Open the Deployment Configuration File and set the value for Objects Enabled to false.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Configuration File and set the value for Objects Enabled to false.

segment.source: If you made any changes to the Deployment Configuration file after sequencing, ensure that the plug-in package is published with the file.
segment.target: If you made any changes to the Deployment Configuration file after sequencing, ensure that the plug-in package is published with the file.

segment.source: Ensure that the Connection Group you created is enabled onto your desired computer.
segment.target: Ensure that the Connection Group you created is enabled onto your desired computer.

segment.source: The Connection Group created will likely “pend” if the Office 2013 App-V package is in use when the Connection Group is enabled.
segment.target: The Connection Group created will likely “pend” if the Office 2013 App-V package is in use when the Connection Group is enabled.

segment.source: If that happens, you have to reboot to successfully enable the Connection Group.
segment.target: If that happens, you have to reboot to successfully enable the Connection Group.

segment.source: After you successfully publish both packages and enable the Connection Group, start the target Office 2013 application and verify that the plug-in you published and added to the connection group works as expected.
segment.target: After you successfully publish both packages and enable the Connection Group, start the target Office 2013 application and verify that the plug-in you published and added to the connection group works as expected.

segment.source: Disabling Office 2013 applications
segment.target: Disabling Office 2013 applications

segment.source: You may want to disable specific applications in your Office App-V package.
segment.target: You may want to disable specific applications in your Office App-V package.

segment.source: For instance, you can disable Access, but leave all other Office application main available.
segment.target: For instance, you can disable Access, but leave all other Office application main available.

segment.source: When you disable an application, the end user will no longer see the shortcut for that application.
segment.target: When you disable an application, the end user will no longer see the shortcut for that application.

segment.source: You do not have to re-sequence the application.
segment.target: You do not have to re-sequence the application.

segment.source: When you change the Deployment Configuration File after the Office 2013 App-V package has been published, you will save the changes, add the Office 2013 App-V package, and then republish it with the new Deployment Configuration File to apply the new settings to Office 2013 App-V Package applications.
segment.target: When you change the Deployment Configuration File after the Office 2013 App-V package has been published, you will save the changes, add the Office 2013 App-V package, and then republish it with the new Deployment Configuration File to apply the new settings to Office 2013 App-V Package applications.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To exclude specific Office applications (for example, Access and InfoPath) when you create the App-V package with the Office Deployment Tool, use the ExcludeApp setting.
segment.target: To exclude specific Office applications (for example, Access and InfoPath) when you create the App-V package with the Office Deployment Tool, use the ExcludeApp setting.

segment.source: For more information, see Reference for Click-to-Run configuration.xml file.
segment.target: For more information, see Reference for Click-to-Run configuration.xml file.

segment.source: To disable an Office 2013 application
segment.target: To disable an Office 2013 application

segment.source: Open a Deployment Configuration File with a text editor such as Notepad and search for “Applications."
segment.target: Open a Deployment Configuration File with a text editor such as Notepad and search for “Applications."

segment.source: Search for the Office application you want to disable, for example, Access 2013.
segment.target: Search for the Office application you want to disable, for example, Access 2013.

segment.source: Change the value of "Enabled" from "true" to "false."
segment.target: Change the value of "Enabled" from "true" to "false."

segment.source: Save the Deployment Configuration File.
segment.target: Save the Deployment Configuration File.

segment.source: Add the Office 2013 App-V Package with the new Deployment Configuration File.
segment.target: Add the Office 2013 App-V Package with the new Deployment Configuration File.

segment.source: Re-add the Office 2013 App-V package, and then republish it with the new Deployment Configuration File to apply the new settings to Office 2013 App-V Package applications.
segment.target: Re-add the Office 2013 App-V package, and then republish it with the new Deployment Configuration File to apply the new settings to Office 2013 App-V Package applications.

segment.source: Disabling Office 2013 shortcuts
segment.target: Disabling Office 2013 shortcuts

segment.source: You may want to disable shortcuts for certain Office applications instead of unpublishing or removing the package.
segment.target: You may want to disable shortcuts for certain Office applications instead of unpublishing or removing the package.

segment.source: The following example shows how to disable shortcuts for Microsoft Access.
segment.target: The following example shows how to disable shortcuts for Microsoft Access.

segment.source: To disable shortcuts for Office 2013 applications
segment.target: To disable shortcuts for Office 2013 applications

segment.source: Open a Deployment Configuration File in Notepad and search for “Shortcuts”.
segment.target: Open a Deployment Configuration File in Notepad and search for “Shortcuts”.

segment.source: To disable certain shortcuts, delete or comment out the specific shortcuts you don’t want.
segment.target: To disable certain shortcuts, delete or comment out the specific shortcuts you don’t want.

segment.source: You must keep the subsystem present and enabled.
segment.target: You must keep the subsystem present and enabled.

segment.source: For example, in the example below, delete the Microsoft Access shortcuts, while keeping the subsystems shortcut/shortcut intact to disable the Microsoft Access shortcut.
segment.target: For example, in the example below, delete the Microsoft Access shortcuts, while keeping the subsystems shortcut/shortcut intact to disable the Microsoft Access shortcut.

segment.source: Save the Deployment Configuration File.
segment.target: Save the Deployment Configuration File.

segment.source: Republish Office 2013 App-V Package with new Deployment Configuration File.
segment.target: Republish Office 2013 App-V Package with new Deployment Configuration File.

segment.source: Many additional settings can be changed through modifying the Deployment Configuration for App-V packages, for example, file type associations, Virtual File System, and more.
segment.target: Many additional settings can be changed through modifying the Deployment Configuration for App-V packages, for example, file type associations, Virtual File System, and more.

segment.source: For additional information on how to use Deployment Configuration Files to change App-V package settings, refer to the additional resources section at the end of this document.
segment.target: For additional information on how to use Deployment Configuration Files to change App-V package settings, refer to the additional resources section at the end of this document.

segment.source: Managing Office 2013 package upgrades
segment.target: Managing Office 2013 package upgrades

segment.source: To upgrade an Office 2013 package, use the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: To upgrade an Office 2013 package, use the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: To upgrade a previously deployed Office 2013 package, perform the following steps.
segment.target: To upgrade a previously deployed Office 2013 package, perform the following steps.

segment.source: How to upgrade a previously deployed Office 2013 package
segment.target: How to upgrade a previously deployed Office 2013 package

segment.source: Create a new Office 2013 package through the Office Deployment Tool that uses the most recent Office 2013 application software.
segment.target: Create a new Office 2013 package through the Office Deployment Tool that uses the most recent Office 2013 application software.

segment.source: The most recent Office 2013 bits can always be obtained through the download stage of creating an Office 2013 App-V Package.
segment.target: The most recent Office 2013 bits can always be obtained through the download stage of creating an Office 2013 App-V Package.

segment.source: The newly created Office 2013 package will have the most recent updates and a new Version ID.
segment.target: The newly created Office 2013 package will have the most recent updates and a new Version ID.

segment.source: All packages created using the Office Deployment Tool have the same lineage.
segment.target: All packages created using the Office Deployment Tool have the same lineage.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Office App-V packages have two Version IDs:
segment.target: Office App-V packages have two Version IDs:

segment.source: An Office 2013 App-V Package Version ID that is unique across all packages created using the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: An Office 2013 App-V Package Version ID that is unique across all packages created using the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: A second App-V Package Version ID, x.x.x.x for example, in the AppX manifest that will only change if there is a new version of Office itself.
segment.target: A second App-V Package Version ID, x.x.x.x for example, in the AppX manifest that will only change if there is a new version of Office itself.

segment.source: For example, if a new Office 2013 release with upgrades is available, and a package is created through the Office Deployment Tool to incorporate these upgrades, the X.X.X.X version ID will change to reflect that the Office version itself has changed.
segment.target: For example, if a new Office 2013 release with upgrades is available, and a package is created through the Office Deployment Tool to incorporate these upgrades, the X.X.X.X version ID will change to reflect that the Office version itself has changed.

segment.source: The App-V server will use the X.X.X.X version ID to differentiate this package and recognize that it contains new upgrades to the previously published package, and as a result, publish it as an upgrade to the existing Office 2013 package.
segment.target: The App-V server will use the X.X.X.X version ID to differentiate this package and recognize that it contains new upgrades to the previously published package, and as a result, publish it as an upgrade to the existing Office 2013 package.

segment.source: Globally publish the newly created Office 2013 App-V Packages onto computers where you would like to apply the new updates.
segment.target: Globally publish the newly created Office 2013 App-V Packages onto computers where you would like to apply the new updates.

segment.source: Since the new package has the same lineage of the older Office 2013 App-V Package, publishing the new package with the updates will only apply the new changes to the old package, and thus will be fast.
segment.target: Since the new package has the same lineage of the older Office 2013 App-V Package, publishing the new package with the updates will only apply the new changes to the old package, and thus will be fast.

segment.source: Upgrades will be applied in the same manner of any globally published App-V Packages.
segment.target: Upgrades will be applied in the same manner of any globally published App-V Packages.

segment.source: Because applications will probably be in use, upgrades might be delayed until the computer is rebooted.
segment.target: Because applications will probably be in use, upgrades might be delayed until the computer is rebooted.

segment.source: Managing Office 2013 licensing upgrades
segment.target: Managing Office 2013 licensing upgrades

segment.source: If a new Office 2013 App-V Package has a different license than the Office 2013 App-V Package currently deployed.
segment.target: If a new Office 2013 App-V Package has a different license than the Office 2013 App-V Package currently deployed.

segment.source: For instance, the Office 2013 package deployed is a subscription based Office 2013 and the new Office 2013 package is Volume Licensing based, the following instructions must be followed to ensure smooth licensing upgrade:
segment.target: For instance, the Office 2013 package deployed is a subscription based Office 2013 and the new Office 2013 package is Volume Licensing based, the following instructions must be followed to ensure smooth licensing upgrade:

segment.source: How to upgrade an Office 2013 License
segment.target: How to upgrade an Office 2013 License

segment.source: Unpublish the already deployed Office 2013 Subscription Licensing App-V package.
segment.target: Unpublish the already deployed Office 2013 Subscription Licensing App-V package.

segment.source: Remove the unpublished Office 2013 Subscription Licensing App-V package.
segment.target: Remove the unpublished Office 2013 Subscription Licensing App-V package.

segment.source: Restart the computer.
segment.target: Restart the computer.

segment.source: Add the new Office 2013 App-V Package Volume Licensing.
segment.target: Add the new Office 2013 App-V Package Volume Licensing.

segment.source: Publish the added Office 2013 App-V Package with Volume Licensing.
segment.target: Publish the added Office 2013 App-V Package with Volume Licensing.

segment.source: An Office 2013 App-V Package with your chosen licensing will be successfully deployed.
segment.target: An Office 2013 App-V Package with your chosen licensing will be successfully deployed.

segment.source: Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office
segment.target: Deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office

segment.source: The following table describes the requirements and options for deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office.
segment.target: The following table describes the requirements and options for deploying Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office.

segment.source: Task
segment.target: Task

segment.source: Details
segment.target: Details

segment.source: How do I package and publish Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office?
segment.target: How do I package and publish Visio 2013 and Project 2013 with Office?

segment.source: You must include Visio 2013 and Project 2013 in the same package with Office.
segment.target: You must include Visio 2013 and Project 2013 in the same package with Office.

segment.source: If you aren’t deploying Office, you can create a package that contains Visio and/or Project, as long as you follow the Virtualizing Microsoft Office 2013 for Application Virtualization (App-V) 5.0.
segment.target: If you aren’t deploying Office, you can create a package that contains Visio and/or Project, as long as you follow the Virtualizing Microsoft Office 2013 for Application Virtualization (App-V) 5.0.

segment.source: How can I deploy Visio 2013 and Project 2013 to specific users?
segment.target: How can I deploy Visio 2013 and Project 2013 to specific users?

segment.source: Use one of the following methods:
segment.target: Use one of the following methods:

segment.source: If you want to...
segment.target: If you want to...

segment.source: ...then use this method
segment.target: ...then use this method

segment.source: Create two different packages and deploy each one to a different group of users
segment.target: Create two different packages and deploy each one to a different group of users

segment.source: Create and deploy the following packages:
segment.target: Create and deploy the following packages:

segment.source: A package that contains only Office - deploy to computers whose users need only Office.
segment.target: A package that contains only Office - deploy to computers whose users need only Office.

segment.source: A package that contains Office, Visio, and Project - deploy to computers whose users need all three applications.
segment.target: A package that contains Office, Visio, and Project - deploy to computers whose users need all three applications.

segment.source: If you want only one package for the whole organization, or if you have users who share computers:
segment.target: If you want only one package for the whole organization, or if you have users who share computers:

segment.source: Follows these steps:
segment.target: Follows these steps:

segment.source: Create a package that contains Office, Visio, and Project.
segment.target: Create a package that contains Office, Visio, and Project.

segment.source: Deploy the package to all users.
segment.target: Deploy the package to all users.

segment.source: Use Microsoft AppLocker to prevent specific users from using Visio and Project.
segment.target: Use Microsoft AppLocker to prevent specific users from using Visio and Project.
